captions.text:
Weird question - how often would you say foreign 
objects get traumatically inserted into your body

during an average week? Maybe once at most, and 
usually with your consent? Well tell that to Ethan

Winters, or as I&#39;ve come to call him, the amazing 
human desk tidy. It&#39;s seriously tarnishing his

&quot;average everyman in a crisis&quot; image the sheer 
amount of random sharp objects he gets stuck

in him in the course of Resident Evil 7 and 8, by 
the end it&#39;s just gotten silly. I know he doesn&#39;t

ask for any of it but you know what they say, 
if everyone you meet is an impalement weirdo,

maybe the impalement weirdo is you. At 
the start of Resident Evil Vilililillage,

Ethan &quot;Unluckiest Chump In The Western Hemisphere&quot; 
Winters is lounging around the house with his wife

and baby thinking his getting impaled on things 
days are behind him when of all people Chris

Redfield bursts in, shoots Mrs. Winters dead 
and kidnaps the baby. This, boys and girls,

is what we call a &quot;hook.&quot; But don&#39;t worry, 
it&#39;s like what they used to do with superhero

comics where the cover shows Superman about to 
dropkick a baby into a volcano or something to

force you to buy the comic and discover, oh, 
turns out all along it was a volcano-shaped

sweet shop and it&#39;s the baby&#39;s birthday. 
So obviously there&#39;s an explanation for Chris&#39;

actions, one that I feel he could have 
summarised to Ethan easily enough before

or during the home invasion without having to beat 
him unconscious with a rifle butt. Chris just felt

like being a real dick about it for some reason, 
maybe he couldn&#39;t find a boulder to punch that

morning. Anyway, various other things go wrong and 
Ethan gets trapped in a weird isolated village of

monsters and must rescue his baby daughter from 
the monster leaders. Now, Resident Evil has had

its ups and downs in my view, mainly downs, and 
specifically two ups: Resident Evil 4 and Resident

Evil 7. And Vilililage is best summarised as what 
you&#39;d get at the exact midpoint between those

two games. So from 7 we have the first person 
gameplay that again feels like we&#39;re piloting a

refrigerator box balanced on a Roomba, as well 
as essentially the same plot beat for beat:

Ethan gets toyed with by family of psychos, 
kills them one by one, discovers something

near the end that ties it to the overarching 
Resident Evil story the way one ties the leash

of a perfectly satisfactory dog to the front 
of a combine harvester, the only difference is

the acreage over which it all takes place.
And from Resident Evil 4 we take the gothic

B-movie vibe, inventory system, quirky merchant 
character and associated weapon upgrade mechanics

and basically the whole setting, isolated 
village in open quotes &quot;Europe.&quot; &quot;Europe,&quot; eh? So

somewhere between Manchester and Istanbul, then. 
&quot;Hey, we should probably do something to seem like

we&#39;re not just entirely copying RE4&#39;s homework.&quot; 
&quot;Hm. What&#39;s the exact opposite of a tiny castle

owning man?&quot; &quot;A giant castle owning woman! 
Genius! Fish fingers all round!&quot; Yeah, sorry

if you got into that whole meme that arose around 
Lady Dimitrescu, because whoops, she&#39;s only the

boss of the first area, she dies like two hours 
in. And then it&#39;s back to fantasizing about your

high school French teacher in a milkmaid outfit. 
So I find myself disappointed by Vilililage. On

broad analysis, at least. The moment to moment 
combat is sufficiently weighty and brutal,

although I would say the difficulty feels a bit 
low on standard level, I somehow never ran out

of ammo or items and yet simultaneously never 
ran low on inventory space, testament perhaps

to Ethan Winters&#39; dad-level suitcase-packing 
ability. But consider it recommended if all

you want is another ten hours of Resident 
Evil brand distraction to kill time before

you collect your most discerning motherfucker in 
the universe award, but I was hoping for more.

Yahtzee, Resident Evil 4 and 7 were your two 
highlights of the series, surely a game that

combines them must be everything you&#39;d want, 
right? Wrong. Dirty boy. No mommy milkies for

you. First of all, it&#39;s hard to appreciate the 
creativity on display when so many of its moments

and mechanics are copied beat for beat from 
its two main influences. But more importantly,

4 and 7 were good for different reasons. 4 
was amusingly camp and action-focused and

grand in scope but 7 was survival-focused and 
benefited from a narrowing of scope that made

it effectively unnerving. 8 as a result is a 
severely mixed bag. How mixed? Put it like this:

there is a moment in Vililililage that was the 
most genuinely terrifying horror experience I&#39;ve

had in a video game for a very long time. There 
is another moment some time later where you&#39;re

in a dreary repetitive industrial environment 
fighting cyborgs and it&#39;s about as scary and

exciting as trying to squeeze past a Borg 
cosplayer on a narrow staircase. And when I

say &quot;moment&quot; I mean about an hour. This is part of 
the decline the game suffers after mommy milkies

has spooged herself out of the game and after 
the really effective horror part - it&#39;s the bit

in the dollhouse, alright, I presume it&#39;s okay 
for a review to identify the bit it&#39;s praising,

I dunno, you people cry spoilers if I so much as 
tell you Ethan Winters&#39; inside leg measurement.

Anyway, the point is that&#39;s the peak, and there&#39;s 
only one way to go from a peak. The game&#39;s

all over the place by the end. All the global 
conspiracy shit leaks in from the other games

like brown urine from an overloaded nappy, there&#39;s 
a bit where we have to play as Chris Redfield and

it turns into a military shooter, I didn&#39;t even 
mention that the industrial area ends with Ethan

Winters having to pilot a fucking mech suit with 
a chainsaw arm and an infinite gatling gun. And

before you say that sounds cool you predictable 
mouthbreathing Marvel movie enjoying fucks,

think of the start of RE7 where you&#39;re in a shed 
fighting off a crazy wife in her workout pumps

and how infinitely more effective it was than 
any of this nonsense. The sinking feeling I got

from Chris Redfield&#39;s appearance at the end of 7 
has proved entirely justified. The way Vilililage

shifts the story&#39;s focus to the stodgy old git 
towards the end feels like a misstep after the

breath of fresh air that Ethan Winters has 
been to Resident Evil protagonists. Oh boy,

someone new and human and relatable who we&#39;ve not 
yet witnessed do something really embarrassing

like be in Resident Evil 5. As a series Resident 
Evil just can&#39;t seem to kick the habit.

Every now and again it pulls its head out of 
its bum for one game but just can&#39;t resist that

wonderful butthole smell and is six inches deep 
again by the sequel. So of course we discover how

the events of the last two games tie into the 
fucking Umbrella corporation and there&#39;s a new

bonkers global conspiracy to create monsters and 
sell them as weapons because it&#39;s nice how guns

straightforwardly murder whatever we point them 
at but maybe if there was a chance your weapon

could turn around and suck your eyeballs out then 
that&#39;d add enough je ne sais quoi to stand out in

a competitive marketplace. It&#39;s like Resident 
Evil is a restaurant that&#39;s been trying to sell

octopus burgers and no-one fucking likes the 
octopus burgers &#39;cos they&#39;re slimy and weird

and the eyeballs look like they&#39;re judging me, so 
then they bring out a nice burger with no octopus

and it sells really well and the managers all 
go &quot;Great, now how do we work the octopus back

into this?&quot; FORGET ABOUT THE FUCKING OCTOPUS. 
THE OCTOPUS DOESN&#39;T WORK. WHY DO YOU ALWAYS

INSIST ON PUSHING THE OCTOPUS? ARE YOU TRYING 
TO LAUNDER A MARINE LIFE SMUGGLING ENTERPRISE?
